sub_topic: Prove that the Cartesian product of two sets is not commutative.
message_1:
Let A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {4, 5}.
What is the Cartesian product of A and B? What is the size of the Cartesian product of A and B?
What is the Cartesian product of B and A? What is the size of the Cartesian product of B and A?
Do your answers show that the Cartesian product of two sets is not commutative?
message_2:
The Cartesian product of A and B, denoted as A x B, is the set of all ordered pairs (a, b) where a is an element of A and b is an element of B. 

A x B = {(1, 4), (1, 5), (2, 4), (2, 5), (3, 4), (3, 5)}

The size of the Cartesian product of A and B is the number of elements in A x B. Since there are 3 elements in A and 2 elements in B, the size of A x B is 3 * 2 = 6.

The Cartesian product of B and A, denoted as B x A, is the set of all ordered pairs (b, a) where b is an element of B and a is an element of A.

B x A = {(4, 1), (4, 2), (4, 3), (5, 1), (5, 2), (5, 3)}

The size of the Cartesian product of B and A is the number of elements in B x A. Since there are 2 elements in B and 3 elements in A, the size of B x A is 2 * 3 = 6.

Comparing A x B and B x A, we can see that the elements in these sets are different, even though their sizes are the same. This shows that the Cartesian product of two sets is not commutative, as A x B â‰  B x A.
